I'm a piano player and I've sat in on several tunings... Tuning a piano is not impossible or a science... it's an art. The fundamental pitch (usually middle C)is achieved using some type of tuner. every not above is slightly sharper and every note below is lightly flatter in equal temperament except the octaves. To achieve the best sound the intervals like fifths fourths and thirds are fine tuned to each other using your ear to discern resonant frequencies called beats when the pitchs clash against each other... octaves are the most tuned to each other so that they produces overtones when one note is struck... and each side string is tuned to the middle string so that the note when struck sustains the frequency of the pitch over a time chosen by the person tuning the piano. No two pianos are exactly the same and each sound produced through tuning is a work of art!

0:50 I don't think "2 to 3" is a perfect fifth. according to equal temperament, which is applied on pianos, a perfect fifth is "1 to 2^(7/12)".
If a perfect fifth were indeed two to three, then the frequency of E5 note, which is the fifth of A4 note whose frequency is 440Hz, would be 440*1.5=660. But the ACTUAL frequency of the E5 note according to equal temperment, which is used on piano, is ACTUALLY 659.25Hz, which is round 440*2^(7/12)=659.2551138Hz.

Incorrect. Strings, such as the strings on a violin, do not vibrate in sine waves. In fact, they vibrate in complex wave forms in which the overtones have irregularly proportioned amplitudes. The sine wave is a "pure" tone which does not produce irregular strength overtones. You are confusing "frequency" with "sine wave." All instruments have different timbres, a function in part of the irregularly distributed overtone amplitudes (as well as the envelope and other parameters.) you are presenting the concept of equal temperament correctly but have botched timbre and the term "sine wave." And, pianos do NOT produce sine waves. Pianos have complex overtone structures, and the attack envelope of the piano contributes to the piano string timbre. Some acousticians, like myself, consider the clarinet sound to be fairly sinusoidal though it is not actually a pure tone, as in the sine wave, and has increased relative amplitudes on the odd harmonics. But, to reiterate, no acoustic instruments produce pure tones or sine waves. And not the human voice.

Good video as far as it goes. BUT, there is another physical effect that comes into play when playing two piano notes at the same time. It is called enharmonicity and it is caused by the fact that the vibrating partials of the string are slightly shorter than the theoretical and thus slightly sharper in pitch. The entire tuning is thus slightly stretched as one moves outward from a given anchor pitch (A4 = 440 Hz).

I've been doing occasional piano tuning since the 1970s, and always used the old method of stretching the fourths (+ 1 beat per second), compressing the fifths (- 3 beats in five seconds), and double-checking the process with the major thirds. This approximates the twelfth-root method. Then you have to start stretching the octave once you get to two Cs above middle C by a factor of two beats per second because it will sound flat to the ear otherwise, even if tuned to the perfect frequency. Most electronic keyboards that I have heard do not take this into consideration and they sound a little flat to me in the upper treble section. Some strings on some cheaper pianos will have false beats, meaning they will wah-wah-wah no matter what you do. Piano tuning involves some major compromises and is a bit of an art.

Yeah, the problem explained in the video is one of the problems with tuning a piano, but it isn't the only one.  Piano tuners generally don't even tune the notes to be exactly the twelvth root of two apart across the entire keyboard.  They tend to make the octaves get slightly wider (or "stretched") as you go up or down from the middle of the keyboard, since this makes the piano sound more in tune.  The extremely low strings, for example, are so thick and stiff that dissonant harmonics sound sufficiently loudly so that has to be taken into account.  (This is especially so on smaller pianos, which have shorter strings, so that they have to be extra thick to get the low notes, and it's less prevalent on larger pianos, such as concert grand 9-10 foot long ones.)  A real piano tuner can probably come up with even more compromises they have to make in reality, beyond I've mentioned here.  Piano tuning really is "the art of compromise".

This is a great video, thank-you for sharing! There is one point which had me confused on first-watching though, so I'd like to clear it up.

When you say that you can tune a guitar (as opposed to a piano) by harmonics, I think this is misleading, because it depends on what you mean by tune. I think there is a danger of confusing this as an instrument specific issue, rather than a general mathematical property.

The fundamental issue that you explained so well is that no equal tempered scale can give both a perfect octave and a perfect fifth (and a fourth etc.). The reason the chromatic scale is so nice is that it does such a good job of approximating those simple harmonics (cf. @3Blue1Brown's comment and wonderful video). Your piano illustration does a great job of explaining this, but I don't think there is anything special about the piano here, compared to any other instrument, and the same problem will persist for the guitar, say (assuming you also want it to follow the same equal tempered chromatic scale).

Indeed, you may proceed to tune your guitar by starting with the low E-string (for example, equalizing it with the E on your piano) then equalizing the 4th harmonic on that E-string with the 3rd harmonic on the A-string (cf 1:40). That will give you a perfect fourth, but now your A string is no longer actually an A (according to the definition of the equally tempered chromatic scale, at least). To see this, all you have to do is compare it with the A on your piano! They will be out of phase, because of the very issue you just described for the piano!

Again, let me stress, this is an awesome video, and I learned a lot. But initially I was confused by what is special about the piano here, compared to the guitar, and so I wanted to clear up that there is nothing special about the piano, and the problem is still there for the guitar.

Please let me know if you have any comments, or if I got something wrong! :)

Equal temperament applies to all instruments, not just the piano, and replaced Pythagorean tuning about 400-500 years ago, because of problems relating to the "Pythagorean Gap". The idea of a "perfect fifth" etc. is from Pythagorean days, so "being out of tune" in this regard is a technicality rather than a statement of fact. Our ears have become accustomed to equal temperament tuning and do not hear it as out of tune.

octave: 2/1 = 2
fifth: 3/2 = 1.5, 2^(7/12) = 1.498
fourth: 4/3 = 1.333, 2^(5/12) = 1.335
major third: 5/4 = 1.25, 2^(4/12) = 1.260

major second: 9/8 = 1.125, 2^(2/12) = 1.122

minor sixth: 8/5 = 1.6, 2^(8/12) = 1.587

The elder statesman in our family (musically speaking) was my dad’s older brother, Joseph Metzger. He learned to play the violin and tune pianos about a hundred years ago. Dad was a finish carpenter and also very good at reupholstering furniture. I started violin lessons in 1950. Uncle Joe taught Dad how to tune pianos about 1970 and Dad said it was the most difficult thing he had ever studied. Later in that decade, Dad taught me how to tune pianos.

Did you ever mop a floor? If you used only one bucket of water, the part of the floor you mopped last was only as clean as the dirty water, right?

Learning to temper the scale (so the piano would sound equally good in any key) was challenging but tuning a piano is similar to mopping that floor. Pianos are made partly of metal and mostly of wood. If the average pitch of the piano is significantly below standard pitch (A-440 = C-523.3) - which was the case for many of the pianos I tuned in people’s homes - tuning the hundreds of strings actually compresses the piano frame. If you start by tuning one string of each note of an octave near the middle of the piano and then tune the other hundreds of strings, the first strings that were tuned are then below the pitch to which they were first tuned. (The same thing happens when tuning a violin that is badly out of tune.)

If you go dump out the dirty water and get clean water in your bucket and mop the floor a second time, the floor will be cleaner than it was when you finished mopping it the first time. But if the water is even slightly dirty after the second mopping, the part of the floor you mopped last is still slightly dirty. How many times should you repeat the process?

Same with tuning a neglected piano that is measurably below standard pitch before you begin. If you tune it twice, it will be closer to standard pitch than if you tune it only once.

You might think, why not raise the pitch on the first tuning a specific percentage of a semitone so the average pitch will be very close to standard pitch before you begin tuning the piano a second time?

Problem: Different pianos - even different models from a given manufacturer - have different coefficients of compression of their frames as tension is added.

Of the various things I have done - printing, managing a factory, etc. - piano tuning was the thing (for which I was paid) that I liked the most and did the longest but, by 2007, I couldn’t hear the pitch of the highest treble notes well enough so, when my wife and I moved away from where our son lived, I gave him my piano tuning tools to keep as keepsakes.

If anyone is interested in the “theology in a piano”, let me know.

As a teacher and as a recovered piano tuner... I got as far as "The more bumps.. the higher the pitch"....
how about....
" humans perceive faster vibrations as higher pitch"
and
"String naturally vibrate as one whole length, and at the same time in smaller/shorter lengths at the same time, just like the ocean can have huge swells and between the swells the can be smaller waves too... all at the same time".
and
the whole string ( the primary or "Fundamental note ") and the smaller partials, and even smaller partial/portions ( overtones) of the string each and all produce their own pitches or notes at the same time
and
a string of a certain (combination of ) length, tightness and thickness ( or mass/weight) will vibrate a a certain speed. Change any variable and the pitch changes.... tighten the string and the fundamental and all of the overtones go up.... or shorten the length , and the pitch goes up. an vice versa.

Back to the overtones....
As previously stated, A string vibrates as a whole, and vibrates in smaller ( very predictable/ consistent) lengths. The whole string, two half portions, four quarter sections. and other portions. And the "half portions" produce a pitch and octave higher, and the quarter sections produce a pitch two octaves higher.
BUT !!! the actual "Stack" or "Overtone series" of shorter and shorter ( higher and higher partials/overtones) are,, ( in higher and higher pitches)
Fundamental, then octave, fifth, octave, third, fifth, octave, third, fourth, fifth, octave.... and every partial all at the same time.... in smaller and smaller pieces of string

BUT THERE'S A PROBLEM !!!
"In theory " a string of a certain length vibrates at a certain speed" and " it's HALF LEGTHS will vibrate at twice the speed .. or "an octave higher" BUT !!!

If a whole length of string is 20 inches then "half lengths" would be 10 inches. But there is a dead spot between vibrating sections called the NODE.... and the NODE steal a little length... so unfortunately "one half of 20 inches isn't 10 inches.... IT'S 9.7 ( or something like that) so the octave length is a little short so the octave pitch is a little sharp.!!! and this "error" gets worse and worse as we go "Up" the harmonic stack ( overtones".... This error is called "Enharmonicity"

So when a piano tuner is tuning a "High A" four octaves up.... he tunes that string to be in tune with the Very Sharp Overtone.... NOT "A2 = A6" ( four octaves).... and ALL of the overtones in EVERY NOTE / STRING are sharp!!!. so a piano tuner's job is to make 88 compromises. And.... if you have good hearing,,, play any not on the middle of the keyboard... and then play the highest similar note... ( A to high A).... dont be confused if the high A sounds WAAAAAY Sharp... it should be,,, because its tuned NOT to the lower A.... but to the very sharp overtone PARTIAL in that string.

p.s. "Enharmonicity" became a greater phenonm when piano design added a very strong internal cast iron framing ( called the plate)... it looks like a a big brass collored harp.... Plates were incorporated so that strong wires ( strings) could be used which could be pulled MUCH tighter... which provided a LOT more brilliance, volume and tone. By the way although not the ONLY BIG DIfference.... a piano has a Volume dynamic range but a harpsichord ( Lurch-Adams Family) has NO dynamic range.... and the "REAL" name of a piano is the "Piano-Forte" ( The keyboard that can play soft AND loud)

If anyone's wondering how the rational root theorem works, here's a rough proof, as well as I could do in a youtube comment section.

Proof: Assume for a contradiction that there exists a, b, nin the natural numbers, and n > 1 s.t. (a/b) ^n = 2

==> a^n/b^n = 2
==> a^n = 2b^n
Notice that if you take some odd number to any power, it remains forever odd.
Thus, ==> a must be even
Let a = 2k for some k in the natural numbers.

That gives us 2^n × k^n = 2b^n
==> b^n = 2^(n-1) × k^n

Since n > 1,that implies 2^(n-1) >= 2
Thus, b^n is even and by the same reasoning b is also even
Let b = 2r
However, that brings us to:
2^n × k^n = 2^(n+1)r^n
k^n = 2*r^n

We arrive at the same thing at the start.
Thus, that would mean there are no solutions, since they'd have to be infinitely large

So basically, in stupid people words. The chords that we use in classical music theory almost line up perfectly on the 12 semitone octave scale we use on our instruments. Almost. The unsolvable problem is that the first note on an octave must be half the frequency of the last note on the octave. If we don't do this then they aren't the same note and It doesn't harmonize, so it sounds awful. It would also mean that every octave above and below would be offset and sound progressively worse as you continued.

Equal temperament means we just divide an octave into 12 equally distanced slices and tune each string accordingly. But none of the chords we use correspond to the slices we have.

Therefore with a physical instrument there is no way to tune it where you can play all chords perfectly and an octave has the exact perfect distance simultaneously. The best you can do is space the notes out equally and play all the chords slightly out of tune.
This is also why you don't tune a guitar with harmonics, it won't be tempered.

This "Out of tune" talk is a little excessive.
The nowadays western music in general is played in the chromatic scale. In the chromatic scale there is no perfect harmonic intervals, and all the 12 notes has a basic frequency precisely defined.
But it does not means "out of tune", it is just not perfect harmonic (rational multiple frequency) intervals.
Some instruments like Trombones has a tendency to play harmonics intervals cause the physic construction, but the musician can force the pitch "on the fly" to mach the chromatic scale. Some instruments like violins can play any notes and intervals (harmonic or not).

Yes, if you use only instruments like violins etc you can compose and execute a whole symphony with perfect harmonic intervals, but people in general will not perceive the difference if you execute the same symphony using the chromatic scale.

Our frequency detector, the cochlea, is not so precise. Even yawning make the cochlea shift frequency by more than 2 exponent 1/12.
To make things more complicated, the first processing operation of the brain is to abstract away precise frequency.
View it as a sliding window where, in the middle, is the fundamental frequency.
Hearing is studying the shape of the the spectrogram around the peak frequency.
Let me make it clear:
First of all, there is an "AGC", automatic gain control, managed by the autonomous nerve system. So, you can not tell the absolute intensity of the original sound because this old nerve system doesn't communicates with the new nerve system.
Second, an automatic sliding window makes the peak frequency always centered. Even if this system is managed by the new nerve system, it is automatic and don't provide information to the next layers of the hearing system.
Now, all the information available for speech decoding is that stabilized sliding window with curve representing the intensity level of each frequencies over one octave and a second view is the relative intensity of the harmonics.
The next steps is to associate this evolving shape with the output of different scale delay array. In other word, assign a relative time to the harmonic curve.

Just to clear things up a little bit - it is possible to tune a piano using ratios. It's called just intonation, and it sounds really pure. The reason next to no pianos use it is because just intonation scales have a "centerpoint" note that all other notes are tuned around. If the centerpoint is C, then a C chord will sound really nice, but a C# chord will sound horrible.

For those who didn't understand; basically the reason is the same reason you can't square the circle. You're dealing with a number that's irrational, which can't be expressed (pi in the case of the math problem, the 12th root of 2 in the case of the piano tuning), so they'll never be perfectly tuned because we can't perfectly use this number in practice. And you can't tune with harmonics because it has so many different strings (Not 4 like a violin), and the octave will always be off if you attempt to tune with harmonics (ie, tune based on perfect fifths being a ratio of 3/2, etc) which is the way we tune other instruments. Some approximation of the 12th root of 2 gives the best results, but still NOT mathematical perfect. This is the best way I could sum it.

The issues raised in this video actually effect most instrument in an identical or similar form. Saxophones for example are flat on some notes and sharp on others. Only trained professionals contain the skill to hear tunings between each note and adjust for it. If the player does not adjust, than the resulting sound issues are similar to the piano in the sense that they are not playing perfectly in-tune. String ensembles also adjust for it. Choirs often sing in pure intonation unless they have piano accompaniment, in that case they likely are singing in equal temperament and have the same tuning issues.

The other issue is that this video only explains the theoretical. In reality, every material and instrument has its own properties that effects the numbers displayed in this video. Piano tuners realize that every single piano has different string tensions and specific required adjustments to take proper tunings. Partially due to string length which is likely not exact to the many decimal points and because pianos and other instruments are not static, the materials expand and contract due to circumstances such as humidity, season, temperature, and etc.

Concert pianists especially would be surprised to hear that it is 'impossible to tune a piano' - a remarkably silly assertion presumably made by someone with no musical training and no 'ear' for musical pitch. 'Perfectly tuned' depends on the temperament chosen and the musical considerations rather than the physics of sound. There are a number of tunings available - equal temperament, Werkmeister, Valoti, mean tone etc. with equal temperament tuning of e.g., the piano being by far the most common. Equal temperament is only necessary when the instrument is expected to be able  play in all major and minor keys with 'acceptable' intonation. If the instrument, e.g. a harpsichord, is only required to play in a more limited range of keys, a temperament best suited to that range of keys is used, e.g. Valotti. A harpsichord can be tuned to satisfy the tonality of the limited range of keys, and is therefore more 'perfectly' tuned than an equal temperament piano would be for that range of keys, but the harpsichord would sound more 'out-of-tune' than a equal temperament piano in the more obscure keys. This is not a subject 'minutephysics' is equipped to adequately discuss. Very superficial. Sheep gut, not 'cat gut'.

Allow me to clear up some confusion:

I’ve seen many comments below from people that think Henry got it wrong, because “obviously pianos can be tuned”.
As with many armchair experts on the internet that can’t be bothered to do a modicum of research before they chime, there are doubters. I’m here to tell you Henry is spot-on correct.

We are a dying breed us aural piano tuners. I can argue that there are fewer than 2,000 people on the planet today that truly know how to tune a concert piano by ear. Every single one of us is in demand like never before due to software. Software tuning is getting very good compared to what it once was, but all professional piano tuning software STILL must pIt itself against an aural judge before it is released. Aural piano tuning is a learned skill that requires years of practice- no matter how “perfect” you think your pitch is.

I’m going to make several statements below about western tuning in general, and then some specific statements about the industry of piano tuning itself. Stay with me:

1) It is not possible to tune all 12 notes of the western scale simultaneously. (That’s the point of Henry’s video)

2) The history of Western composition itself is deeply rooted in the limitations of 12 notes being in tune. Until recently, composers simply avoided the out of tune notes. Right up until the late Baroque. Check out Chant to hear what 800 years of music sounded like before Josquin des Prez and the Renaissance.

3) IMPORTANT! All instruments of the (professional) modern orchestra or choir constantly alter pitch flat or sharp as they perform so as to be in tune at any given moment. They talk and teach amongst themselves as to how to be in tune when they play any interval at any moment. This is the price of 12 note equal temperament. It’s the reason why skilled youth orchestras are always out of tune. Position and embouchure are only learned with experience. And don’t you dare argue me percussion section that has some pitched bells and stuff. Those instruments are out of tune and it’s not your fault.

4) Pianos are a unique exception from #3. Pianos are the ONLY instrument in the orchestra who’s pitch is fixed. As a pianist, you are stuck with the notes the tuner gives you and that’s it. You can’t alter pitch as a pianist. Everybody else can.

5) Pianos are almost impossible to a physicist. High notes are played by small instruments such as the piccolo for a reason. Low notes are played by big instruments such as a bass. Here the problem:
“I want one instrument that plays higher that a piccolo and lower than any bass at the same time. Plus everything in the middle must also be in tune always.”

6) Pianos have an incredible disadvantage that most instruments don’t. It’s called Inharmonicity. Henry didn’t delve here in this video, but it’s only because he must limit his scope of a short video.

7) Pianos are never, ever, EVER, tuned by pitch. That’s the barrier to you musicians that think you know how to tune. Whether or not you tune pianos by ear or software, you simply don’t care about the fundamental (note). You only match coincident partials and forget about the note. Always.

8). There is no such thing as a perfectly tuned piano for all scenarios.
I am called in to tune the same piano 4 days in a row because a solo piano tuning is different that a chamber tuning that is different from a pop recording that is different from jazz. None of this is a secret- it’s simply what pros know.

Tuning a piano is way more complicated than that, regardless of intonation. For a start, each note has three strings and they are not tuned exactly in unison; they are are given "voice" by have a slight dissonance between them. Secondly the bass and treble notes are tuned slightly sharp and flat respectively, as the human ear does not perceive pitch equally from very  low or high notes. Then of course modern pianos are usually tuned to even temperament which  has two notes that are very far from true or "just" intonation..(the perfect third and perfect fifth in particular are bent to fit the scale of equal intervals that allows for unlimited modulation). It is possible to use a compromise intonation like Bach's "mean tone" (often used in pipe organs) but that only allows a certain number of keys to be played in, as modulating too far away from the home keys creates unacceptable dissonance.

You COULD perfectly tune a piano using just tuning, it would just be limited to playing in one key and having to re-tune the piano to play in another, thus the entire point of equal temperament. But the piano isn't the only instrument with this problem; the frets on modern string instruments (like the guitar shown here) are also set to equal temperament. Why? Because otherwise you would have the same problem, having to re-tune the guitar if you wanted to play in a different key. The guitar is permanently tuned to equal temperament via its the fret placement - when you tune a guitar you are merely adjusting the fundamental note of each string, so that the guitar is in tune with itself. The number of strings has nothing to do with; it's a problem of instruments with fixed-pitches vs instruments where the pitch can be slightly adjusted through technique/intonation well playing (fretless stringed instruments, for example). Even then, you might end up with slight tuning errors when playing open strings. On a guitar, equal temperament also allows for the moving of chords and scales around the the fretboard. It's really the best/only solution when you want to play in multiple keys, or use all the notes of the 12-tone system.

As good as his discourse is, he mistates that the octave is the only perfect interval in a tuned piano. But the octave, like all other intervals, must be stretched by a fraction of a cent in the middle of the piano, and by 30 or more cents in the topmost octave more than the C below highest C (for instance).

A simple test of Cs in octaves will show that if the piano octaves are not each stretched more and more the higher in the scale we go, then playing high C with middle C will result in the inescapable impression that the high C is flat. When in fact it may be considerably stretched. I tune the highest note of the piano 50 cents (a quarter tone!) sharp of its theoretical pitch. The lower note, the less the stretch needed, because until we get down into the lower bass notes, the inharmonicity, the stiffness that causes upper harmonics to all run very sharp, is not so acute. But to test a piano for adequate stretch, deliberate distortion from the equally tempered scale that would serve perfectly (for instance, a pipe organ, because a pipe organ has no inharmonicity of stiff strings), play a middle note with, say, three octaves above. Does the trebled octave sound good? If so, it is definitely, whether aurally tuned or machine tuned, very much stretched! IF the highest notes of a piano are insufficiently, ""deliberatelly"" distorted sharp, the arpeggiated chords of the pianist when s/he reaches the highest notes will sound terribly flat: and nothing is worse than being flat when reaching for a high note. The segments of a vibrating piano string are ALL shorter (therefore higher in actual pitch) than their simple divisions would lead you to think. The Octave Harmonic segment of a piano string is not half the string's length. It is LESS than half the string's length because the piano wire is stiff and the non-moving node has a sensible length. And this node is well understood to cause the remaining moving portions of the string to vibrate faster than mere twice the frequency. Thus, stretch is required for every note of a piano.

This should have been called why it is "Just" impossible to perfectly tune a piano. Just tuning pre-dated Equal Temperament. J.S. Bach solved this problem with yet another tuning: Well-Temperament. In fact he also wrote 48 musical pieces (24 in 2 volumes) to demonstrate all major and minor scales can be used with his tuning and not sound out of tune, something impossible to do with Just or Meantone tuning. In band/orchestra, you learned Bb is C#, or an "enharmonic" note, meaning this note is the same, just has two different names. True in equal/well temperament, but not true in Just or Meantone. The situation was so bad before better tuning system that some historical keyboard instruments (mostly pipe organs) have two keys for the "black key", one which is actually Bb, and another which is C#, and when played together, are obviously not the same note. I'm not sure how this topic could be succinctly covered by minutephysics, but it would be genius if it was. This whole area of music theory/history is practically lost because of the dominance of equal temperament. Perhaps starting with the cover of Das wohltemperierte Klavier, and looking at the decorative "swirly line" at the top of the page. Some historic tuning scholars have theorized that is a visualization of how many "cents" you must tune each note up/down to obtain well temperament. Some people attribute no meaning to the swirls other than decoration.

A good professional piano tuner is well aware of the fine-tuned compromises needed to ensure that the piano sounds best for performing in the most likely keys. It's called well-tempering, and Bach produced some music that shows it off. Wendy Carlos produced an album of synthesized music using perfect tuning, as well as well-tempered synthesis; the difference is definitely audible. A few orchestral instruments, notably the trombone and French horn, can be "warped" to provide a better approximation of true-pitch tuning. The oboe is used to provide a reference pitch for the whole orchestra because it is among the least adjustable instruments.

The compromise tuning commonly used on instruments of fixed pitch (piano, guitar, xylophone, etc.) is called TERMERAMENT, and has been around since J. S. This is actually a terrible way to tune a piano. Partially for the reasons shown and partially because the actual harmonics a string carries are sharp of the mathematical whole number ratio anyway. Only a pipe instrument or electronic instrument is slightly out of tune but with perfect octaves as they demonstrate. On a string the fundamentals might follow that model but the harmonics will cause much more interference than they explain. It's beneficial to use your ears to minimize the resulting dissonance. It is of benefit to create some stretching to the scale so that the higher octave is sharp by a small amount. A common method for this rather than just trying a whole bunch of diads up and down the scale wasting a ton of time is to use a fifth plus 1 octave so rather than 2/3 you tune 1/3. This would cause the scale stretch of a circle of fifths to extent over a wider range in a perfect world. But it also forces you to hear the interference of the harmonics and not just the fundamentals so the actual results vary as the strings characteristics change. It's still not perfect but no music is. Electronic instruments could potentially gravitate notes towards a certain frequency if played with other notes to keep harmonies. But for the musician it's important to just understand these problems are there and if they have to fudge a tuning to get a certain feel from a song that's ok because not all harmonies can be true on any instrument. You just do what works best for you.

The only reason you can't truly tune a piano is because the notes in chords are altered depending on what note is played. A minor third and major third have different tuning tendencies, on any instrument other than a piano- these notes can be altered slightly to make the chord as it should sound. The notes being equally the same across the keyboard is nowhere close to as important as this, a .02% alteration in pitch is insignificant compared to the 14 cents needed to lower the third for a major chord, or the 16 cents needed to raise the third for a minor chord. This is why a piano cannot be truly tuned (though what you are saying is also true, but less important), the notes in chords must slightly change in pitch to produce the correct ratios and sound correct to the ear. An untuned chord from a piano will not ring as well as a perfectly tuned chord, but that is impossible to do for more than one chord on a piano.

Your explanation is interesting and well done, but even though it is correct that's not really specific to piano. Actually you explained what equal temperament is, but your statement can be applied to any instrument tuned in equal temperament.

The issue with the piano is that it can not be tuned perfectly even in equal temperament. That comes from the string rigidity; an ideal string should keep its shape after beeing twisted, which is obviously not the case in real life. Because of that, the harmonics are not perfect integers(f,2f,3f,4f...) of the fundamental frequency; for example, the second harmonic of an A 440 Hz has not exactly a frequency of 880 Hz.

That means than if you play this A and the one one octave higher, assuming your the octave is pure, the second harmonic of the low A will clash with the high A(because there's a difference of a few Hz). To minimize this, the piano is somehow tuned wrong deliberately, and there is no perfect solution to that. It's only a matter of compromise.

The thing is, it's also impossible to tune a guitar like this. From E to A there is a fourth, so 4/3. From A to D there is another fourth. So 4/3 again. From D to G a fourth again, so 4/3 again. From G to B there is a major third, so that's 5/4, and from B to E, that's yet another fourth. So 4/3 again. Now (4/3)^4 * 5/4 = 321/81, which is 3.95 and not 4, and that's strange because the E on the top should be exactly two octaves above the E on the bottom. So you can't tune a guitar like that either...

Actually the reason we use 12 notes per octave, is because we want to have an
1-To each frequency you have an another frequency that is 2x that one.
2-Each frequency should be 2x the previous one.
Since both rules combined is not possible, 1 * 1.5 * 1.5 = 2.25 not 2, and 1 *1.5 = 1.5 not 2.
They decided to compromise, (12 root of 2)^7 = 1.4983, this means after 7 keys you have an frequency that is 1.4983 times the previous one, its not the next frequency and not exactly 1.4983 but its there.
Also 53 tones per octave would be an better choice (all ones between 12 and 53 are worst choices than 12), the result would be 1.4999409..., the thing is you would need alot of keys on piano.
Also this is sort of a third rule, not having a huge ass piano.

You forgot to factor in inharmonicity, which further complicates the problem of tuning equal temperament.

Basically, the stiffness of the physical string doesn't create a perfect harmonic. Those harmonics resonate octaves above their fundamental note, but due to stiffness, they resonate slightly sharp of the theoretical frequency they should sound like. Tuners must factor this in as well in order to make playing notes several octaves apart continue to sound pleasant to us. Mathematical tuning will not optimize harmony in a piano. Uprights have the worst of it, because the string length is already being compromised from its ideal length/fundamental pitch ratio to an extreme.

According to the way I tune my customer's acoustic pianos there are at least 5 ways I can viably tune an octave. Because piano strings are not perfectly flexible, like a jump rope, piano strings partials will also be slightly sharp. Because of this, the partial of the fundamental A440 is going to be something like A883 or A884 depending on the string, instead of the normal A880 on other instruments. An octave octave up will be tuned slightly sharper than an octave below in order to compensate harmonically, and the octave down will be tuned slightly flat to the octave up. Once this happens, the partials will match the neighboring octaves fundamentals, and overall harmonicity of the piano tuning will improve.

There is a compromise between equal temperament (any song playable) and harmonics (nice sounds), it's called well temperament . The notes are tuned for example like this:
C: 1/1
C#: 200/189
D: 9/8
D#: 32/27
E: 81/64
F: 4/3
F#: 625/441
G: 3/2
G#: 128/81
A: 27/16
A#: 16/9
B: 189/100
C: 2/1
You still preserve 8 of the fourths as 4/3, while 3 of them will be 75/56 and one of them 83349/62500 (3/2, 112/75 and 12500/83349 for fifths). But they are only off by a few cents, while Pythagorean tuning and meantone have one horrible fifth. Other intervals are nice too.

Edit: This tuning is better:

C: 1/1
C#: 256/243
D: 28/25
D#: 32/27
E: 5/4
F: 4/3
F#: 45/32
G: 3/2
G#: 128/81
A: 375/224
A#: 16/9
B: 15/8
C: 2/1

I guess that was enough to start with for one minute. Beyond what was said, the notes on pianos go slightly sharp as they are sustained in time. I believe all plucked and hammered strings have a tendency to do this, and it is one of the reasons they seem to have a certain sweet sound or lilt. The notes on a piano, until you get to the very low bass, are sounded on three strings, which are slightly detuned from one another. One important reason for this, they say, is that it gives a piano a longer sustain; that is notes don't fade as quickly. Close-ups of the strings in slow motion show that which of the strings is vibrating the most is exchanged among them, the net effect of which is that the note takes longer to fade. It could be that the blurred tonality reduces the effect of the equal-tempered tuning and makes it not sound as discordant.

 It seems to be that when playing most instruments at the highest regarded skill level there is a lot of vibrato (which is vibrating the frequency of the note rapidly.) Which means the impression of a note's precise frequency (if there is any such thing), since that only exists only in the human mind, is what people hear, not a real frequency. Instrumentalists will often say the effect of vibrato and other note-bending is to give the instrument expressiveness more like the human voice, which is often considered the most expressive of all sounds. (Surprise!)

Physicists, to give a better impression that they know what they are talking about when they talk about music, prefer to skip right over the human voice. The most notable (pun!) characteristic of the human voice is the suppression of the fundamental frequency. The harmonics drowned out the fundamental. Yet somehow that faint fundamental frequency is the note. In fact, small, junky speakers will sound as if they are producing low notes that they are incapable of producing (as a fundamental) because of a severe distortion at double the frequency. So the last thing people want if they only have a small speaker is one with low distortion. (Are the audiophiles screaming in outrage right now?)

2:20 This "problem" is not specific to the piano. It's specific to equal-temperament tuning systems, such as 12TET which is used in most modern Western music. The problem manifests all the same when choosing how to space guitar frets in order to divide the octave into 12 halftones. This video makes a big unspoken assumption at 0:50, ie. that the Pythogarean/integer harmonic tuning system is the "correct" one to use as a frame of reference. There is a difference in the definition of "whole step" between the two systems: "9/8" vs "the 6th root of 2". Yes, integer harmonic systems arise more naturally and sound slightly better (depending on circumstance and how good your ear is), but 12TET is the most commonly used system because it uses a small compromise to solve the otherwise super-annoying issue that instrument might need re-tuning to play in a different key.

This is rather poorly presented. The physics is right, but it totally ignores the historical and musical aspects of tuning, which are far more important and interesting. The presenter makes the assumption that Just Intervals (i.e. exact integer frequency ratios) are by default "ideal", especially that the major second should be 9/8. This absurdity is amplified by his explanation that 6 Just major seconds don't make an octave. This is true, but totally misses the point because at no point in history did musicians try to tune by the major second (you'd end up with impure major thirds and impure fifths).

The key point is that the major third and the fifth have historically been (and still are) considered "consonant", but never the major second. The utopian ideal of a tuning system would be such that all the major thirds and fifths (and consequently all the minor thirds) are pure. No one cared about the major second.

Also, the claim that it is impossible to tune a piano "because it has too many strings" is absurd. The problem of tuning doesn't go away on non-keyboard instruments; it just gets covered up by inaccuracy, negligence, vibrato and/or chorus effect.

Generally, on bowed string instruments, particularly in orchestras and quartets, we tune slightly narrow fifths to make sure that the cellos' C string will create a sweet enough third against the violins' E.

Alright, so on a piano where one key is tuned to A at 440Hz, only it and the other A keys are perfectly tuned. But let's say instead of using the approximation method of 12th roots of 2, you just added extra keys. Lots of extra keys which are not "evenly spaced" by a geometric series. You have a set of keys that go up by whole steps, and you have a set of keys that go up by major thirds, and you have a set of keys that go up by fourths, and fifths, and half steps, and every other set you need to complete any possible perfect set of pitches. The goal is that you can start at any key on the board, and from it find another key whose frequency is exactly 9/8 what the one on the first key is. And from that one, you can find a tone that is exactly 4/3 what that key's is, and so on (leaving out the 'non-musical' ratios so we don't have to calculate to arbitrary precision: we don't need 108/107 for example, but I don't know how which ratios Western music theory traditionally uses). To keep it finite though the board has well defined ends at say, N/2 octaves above and below 440. (So if you want N=6 octaves your highest note is 3 octaves above = eight times 440 and your lowest is 3 octaves below = one-eighth of 440).

So for any of you with both the music theory and the mathematical sophistication (Want to waste an afternoon on this, Henry?) to solve this: first, is it possible to create such a board with a finite number of keys (I'm worried about the requirement that you can do any interval from any key already on the board, then any other interval from that one ad infinitum), and if not, what sacrifices must be made to keep the board to a finite number of keys? Further, how many keys will this setup require for a piano of N octaves (or at least an order of magnitude estimate, or at least a solution for N=1 with 440<=f<=880)?

In any case the problem sounds ridiculous and a bit abstract but it's certainly not unreasonable to create such a thing with any number of already existing programs for someone who was either a perfectionist or hardcore audiophile (even though barring the result that the number of necessary keys is reasonably small a simpler pragmatic solution would be to make your program just calculate the ratio associated with the interval you wanted and multiply your current frequency by it to within the precision allowed by your software and repeat this separately for each new tone... But then you lose the ability to loop your music artificially).
...What?

There is a lot more to piano tuning.  The modern default tuning "standard" is higher-pitched than the norm centuries ago, and is "equal-tempered" (uniformly spaced logarithmic scale), so that octaves are exact and every other ratio is only approximate.  In Bach's day, it was common for pianos to be tuned for best results (most exact ratios of small integers) in only one particular key, called "well-tempering".  His "Well-tempered Clavier" exploits its properties; W. Carlos of "Switched-On Bach" fame put out at least one record album using well-tempering.  As somebody else mentioned, common practice for the multiple-wire notes is to spread out the spectrum slightly so that resonances are improved, and piano tuners iteratively tweak the tuning for best overall sound in the most frequently used keys.

So an actual well-tuned piano will not have any perfect intervals at all. All octaves will be slightly wider than 2/1.

You cant really tuned perfectly a piano not because of equally temperant, but because of psychoacoustics (it has to do with sound perception).

As frequencies go too high or too low, our perception tends to "bend" frequencies. So the fine art of piano tunning is compensating with this psychoacoustic, bending the pitch for this extreme frequencies. So you cant use a digital tunner, you have to do it by ear.

As many stated, guitars also are tunned in equal temperament. Tunning with the harmonics of two different strings is a common practice, and I saw great guitar players tunning this way (I remember the great Joe Pass). His guitar sure sound great.

But this harmonics are not (or should not be) the exact same note as the fretted note! As you stated, this harmonics are the "true" tunned notes, as opposite of the notes in the frets that are in equally tuned.

The difference is pretty slight, and guitar intonation is not perfect. But knowing this, I dont rely in tunning with harmonics. If you tune with a digital tunner the open string and then compare the harmonics, you should hear the "wa wa wa wa", the frequency beating.

Probably this slight differences sum up with every string you tune this way, and then you have caos of tunning. Or maybe the not perfect construction of the guitar compensates this. Much people just tune on the fly according of what they are gonna play or playing.

Another "bad practice" of tunning is tunning with a chord. If you tune a chord that some perfect, when you play another chords it will not sound perfect (but maybe as the player is use to that, will make it sound good). It's all about this equally tunning problem you stated with the piano.

The title of this video is a bit misleading. Of course it's possible to tune a piano; people do it all the time. But the problem the videographer tries to discuss is an ancient one, and it applies to any keyboard instrument, since they are complicated and time-consuming to tune, and they can't have enough keys to play all possible notes. I've been reading some of the comments and would like to stick my oar in:

The problem is not harmonics in and of themselves; it's that if you tune a keyboard instrument so that any one key sounds good, related keys will sound passable, but the more distant you get, the more awful the keys will sound. This is because the enharmonic notes (C sharp/D flat, D shapr/E flat, etc.) are actually not the same frequency, a fact which is disguised by the fact that the keyboard uses only one key to accommodate them both. If you tune so that C sharp sounds good in the key you are tuning for (A major, let's say), then D flat is going to sound awful in the keys that use it, and so on. Not to mention the fact that you will have problems even within the key for which you are tuning, since theoretically not all half-steps are the same size. The point of all temperaments is thus to tune all intervals but octaves somewhat sharp or flat, so that all the discord is spread out more or less inaudibly to the ear. Otherwise, you would need to have at least some 420 separate keys to cover five chromatic octaves.

Since you can't retune your average harpsichord, pipe organ, or piano between pieces in a concert, you need some kind of system to adjust the tuning, if you want to be able to play in more than one key. How you will tune depends on what system you choose (the designer of my parish organ decided on Kirnberger III, because most of the hymns in the hymnal are in keys that sound good in this tuning), and there are probably a couple of dozen systems that were evolved over the centuries. In all of them, octaves are pure, but thirds, fourths, and fifths are adjusted to be more or less in tune in some or all keys, and the other pitches are interpolated from there. The equal temperament in general use today makes it possible to play in any key, but many musicians consider it flavorless. Other tuning systems have more flavor, at the cost of reducing the number of keys in which you can play and sound good. To learn more, go to the Web site of the music department at any good university; they will go into great depth about the various known tuning systems and the issues involved.

I was a piano tuner years ago. The poster is refering to tuning an "equal" temperament, which, while not perfect, allows transposition into other keys. And that's only one temperament. However, tuning a piano is somewhat different. Because the strings have mass, this alters the harmonics. Thus, as you move into the higher notes of the piano, it is required that the notes be "stretched", which means they tuned slightly sharp as you ascend on the scale. When you get to the last octave, they can be as much as 20 cents sharp, or more.

Everything in this video is true. However, it's still possible to tune a piano. Since 1926, 440 Hz is the universal standard for the A key on the piano, so every note is tuned relatively to the A key of 440 Hz.

 watch?v=OUvlamJN3nM on 440Hz.

Just to make reality more fun, the reality is that harmonics are not exactly 2x, 3x, 4x etc. It is easy to explain why. (Is there a MinutePhysics covering this?)

Imagine a string. It vibrates in the lowest mode at frequency f. Now image it vibrating at, say, 5 x f. Okay, that's exactly five time, since five half-waves fit perfectly. (Even this far, this physics isn't quite exact, but never mind.) When the instrument is actually played, we have the fundamental f and all (or most) of the harmonics going at the same time.

The fundamental part of the sound causes the string to lengthen. This is easy to see: a straight line is the shortest distance between two points - the ends of the string. A straight line is a silent string. Just because the fundamental is happening, the string is curved, therefore stretched. Of course, steel or catgut (my cat cringes as I write this) it isn't stretching much, but then the fundamental wave isn't much, but the string is indeed longer.

Therefore, the 5th harmonic, the 5xf wave, is fitting five half-waves on a longer distance than the distance between the usual endpoints. Longer wavelength means lower frequency. So, it's a wee bit flat. This goes for all harmonics.

Tuning an instrument beautifully, for a well-trained-ear bearing musician, requires having at least the lower harmonics fit smoothly into the scheme. You can see how it can be a challenge.

This video is great, but it doesn't really get to the second main reason why pianos cannot be tuned perfectly.  Despite equal temperament the physics of a tensioned wire will not allow the wire to vibrate perfectly.  If a string is vibrating at 440 cycles (hertz)(middle A4) per second and you divide the string into two, the two halves will be vibrating at maybe 881...not 880 (which is mathematically twice the number of 440).  Even though mathematically the two halves of the strings should be vibrating at double the frequency of the entire length of the string (fundamental) they cannot physically due to the fact that the very PINPOINT small center of the two vibrating halves (the NODES) act like hinges.  And since hinges, like on a door, have length and take up space they are not part of the vibrating length of the two halves of the string.  So if a string is 4 feet long vibrating at 440hz then the two halves will be ≈1.99999999999 feet long (not 2 feet which is halve of 4) each vibrating at 881hz (not 880).  THIS TERM IS CALLED INHARMONICITY AND IT MEANS THAT EVEN A STRING VIBRATING BY ITSELF IS NOT MATHEMATICALLY IN TUNE.  SO STRINGS DON'T EVEN VIBRATE HARMONICALLY PURE IN PIANOS.  That means the next octave up will have to be tuned at 881 (not 880) and the octave below 440 at 219 (not 220).  The more octaves away from 440 you get the further the discrepancy adds up to where mathematically the bottom note of a piano should vibrate at 27.5hz (low A0), but it probably vibrates anywhere below that number such as 27 or 26.  And to make things worse a single string vibrates at 440, its half at 881, it's quarter at 1764 (not 1762 which is twice 881) and so on with numerous harmonics.  So, which harmonic do we decide to use as a reference when tuning the next octave (A5) higher than A4?  Do we tune using 881 or 1764?  Piano technicians have to compensate and tune either between 881hz and 1764hz.  What's more is that short vertical pianos (spinnets) have thicker strings.  Thicker strings=larger nodes (larger pivot points or larger hinges).  Larger nodes=shorter vibrating half strings lengths.  Shorter vibrating lengths=higher "harmonics".  Higher harmonics=low end of piano will be extremely flat and high end of piano will be extremely sharp.

Great video! This is why piano tuning is as much art as it is science. Another factor not listed here is that the different harmonics in one string itself are often slightly out of tune with themselves. In the days before equal temperament became the standard; different keys would have different "natures", in other words using the same scale degree combinations and chords in one key as you used in another would produce a different effect. Combine that with the well known tendency for human ears to perceive theoretically perfectly tuned intervals as sharp or flat as they get farther apart leads to necessity of "stretch" tuning. The high end of your piano needs to be tuned a little sharp and the low end of the piano needs to be tuned a little flat in order for it to please your ear. While the piano cannot be tuned perfectly according to sound wave physics, it still can be made to sound pleasing to the majority of listeners. Finding that "sweet spot" is the true skill of the piano tuner. It's moot anyway since every piano begins falling out of tune as soon as the tuner is finished. So have your piano tuned by a professional once a year to keep it sounding it's best, even if that best is not theoretically perfect.

All the harmonic series frequencies (the series of pitches that any closed tube makes when buzzed into) can be heard when any brass instrument is played. For example, if you play a BBb tuba into a piano, all of the strings of of harmonic series will vibrate. Thus, when you stop playing, you get the same notes that the tuba was playing and nothing else. The problem is that with the 7th note in the series is Ab, which makes the chord sound out of tune. Now you know why the tuba (or any brass instument) can sound really ugly when played by someone without experience.

"The more bumps, the faster the pitch, and the faster the string has to vibrate"

So in aural tuning what happens is the bottom notes are tuned even lower and the top notes two or three octaves above the middle of the piano are stretched even higher. Actually, the nature of the problem arises from the European Music Theory. For instance, when you go from C to C sharp through the next one, it is accepted that there is a symmetry between flat and sharp. Therefore, interval between C-sharp and C is equal to C-sharp and D. However, in this case, it is impossible to keep the 2:1 ratio among the octave.

On the other hand, chromatic based music theories, Turkish Music, is the most advanced one, there is a ratio of 4 to 5 between sharps and flats. Example, distance between C and C-sharp is 5 units while it is 4 units between C-sharp and D.

Please consider that between notes E - F and C - B should be half step. If you accept them as 5 units, you would get and extra unit through the octave which causes the problem mentioned in the video. Therefore, it is 4 units naturally, which also then is consistent with maths and nature.

In this context, foundation of European music theory had this problem since the beginning. Mathematically, asymmetrical intervals are the only way to keep the ratio 2:1 as well as having a natural harmony.

Please see "Makam" Article, Section "Commas and Accidentals" in Wikipedia for a detailed explanation.

Holy shit, I didn't know that a simple concept such as Mean Intonation vs. Just Intonation could be made so confusing by superfluous math. For anyone who got lost in the over-explanation..

Pure harmonic frequencies (i.e. pretty chord tones as nature intended :P) are ratios of waveforms which are relative to the fundamental/base note, and not their neighboring tones in a musical scale. This is why the 3rd harmonic note in the key of A is not quite the same as the 2nd harmonic note in key of B, despite intuition suggesting that they should be. But they are close enough that musical instrument builders in medieval times decided to split the difference by making 12 equal steps between two octaves. In order for a pianist to play in perfect harmony in all 12 keys, he or she would need 12 different pianos, each calibrated just right for the fundamental note. He or she would also need to swivel around to play a different piano in the middle of a song if the song asked for a key change! Some forms of music still use this pure harmonic system, though, such as Arabic or Hindustani music. This is possible because many instruments used in these traditions do not have frets or fixed intervals, so tiny variations in pitch are possible when playing in different keys. The human voice is also a non-fixed instrument which can adapt to different key changes while adhering to pure harmonic frequencies.

There's a whole nother level of difficulty in tuning a piano. A piano tuned to 12-TET perfection will still not sound quite right because of different string thickness. Thicker strings produce different harmonics (higher pitched), which will not line up with the thinner strings and make it sound out of tune. This is what stretched tuning is for; to make the first harmonic (double the frequency) line up with the key one octave higher (thinner string). The fundamental frequency is therefor a bit flat, but it sounds better in harmony. My two cents (badum tsh).

I'm disappointed with this video. Nothing is stopping you from tuning a piano to a non-ET scale, and in fact just intonation was historically the norm. Equal temperament is not a requirement for tuning a piano. What would have been more interesting, and relevant to the title is to explain the concept of stretched tuning, where low notes are slightly flatter than expected and high notes are slightly sharper. Because of the stiffness of a piano string, the second (and further) harmonics are slightly off from the harmonic series. Stretched tuning means that you tune the piano to pseudo-octaves, such that each octave interval matches the second harmonic mode of the string an octave below it, instead of exactly 2*f. This in my opinion is a valid reason for saying that it's impossible to tune a piano.

in fact, the piano isn't tuned for equal temperament exactly, as the strings on a piano have a thickness, and are thus not perfect harmonic oscillators. Pianos are typically tuned on the railsback curve (known as stretch tuning) to compensate for the non-ideal properties of the strings. The idea is to get the harmonics of the strings to approximately match equal temperament, rather than the fundamentals.

This article is all (more or less) true for instruments such as synthesizers. If we're discussing pianos specifically, their octaves are NOT a perfect 2:1 ratio, but in fact just a tad more. Piano strings aren't perfect theoretical vibrators, and their harmonics are just a bit sharper from where theory would dictate. This means that you'll hear beating on two string tuned a perfect 2:1 ratio. Part of the benefit of a concert grand is that the string lengths can be closer to their ideal lengths, resulting in less of this "stretched tuning."

One other part that's slightly wrong here is that guitars' frets are placed for equal-temperment. If you try tuning two guitar strings so that their harmonics match, as illustrated, your string frequencies won't be quite correct. To get the 2^(1/12) equal temperment, you should tune like this:

A--to A440 tuning fork
low E: tune up until the harmonic almost matches the A. You should hear it beat about every 3 seconds.
D: tune up until it perfectly matches the A... then go just a bit farther until you hear it starting to beat again (about every 2 seconds).
G: tune vs. D, again going just a bit farther until you hear it just starting to beat (about every 1 second).
B: fret it at D and match to the D string's octave. This should match exactly.
high E: match harmonics with A, but tune up to the point it still beats about twice a second. In other words it should sound just slightly flat. Check your work by comparing the B and E strings' harmonics. This should sound just slightly sharp, about twice a second. If not, there's no telling which string you screwed up. Start over.

She'd set up two keyboards- one which she'd play the music on, and the other, which she'd use to set the tuning of the first. It's not true to say that a piano is tuned to equal temperament and a guitar isn't. Tuning the open strings using harmonics is a red herring, the fret distances on a guitar are based on equal temperament even if you tuned the open strings based on harmonics, it's all equal-temperament from there up the rest of the neck. And in fact virtually everyone tunes their open strings to the equal-tempered pitches, usually with a tuner. One of the few exceptions is Eddie Van Halen, who sometimes tunes the B string slightly flat, so it makes an ideal major third with the G string, that way you can play A-shape major chords with distortion that sound as solid as power chords without that muzzy intermodulation jangle you get with an equal-tempered third. Think "Runnin' with the Devil"...
Of course the problem then is that while those major thirds sound fantastic slightly flat, every other note of the scale sounds worse slightly flat, and you find yourself doing slight bends on the B string all the time to bring them up to pitch...

I want to add that you also could use other numbers of tones per octave than 12. This leads to microtonal music. Twelve is used, because it manages to approximate fifth (3:2) and thirds (5:4) very closely. Other numbers that achieve that are, for instance, 19 and 31. You also can try and approximate higher harmonics, like the seventh (7:4). But it's an open problem (as far as I know) to derive all those close-fitting numbers of tones without trial and error.

While the premise is true, you really can't tune a piano perfectly, the reason is not because there are too many strings.  It is because there are not enough strings.  For just one instance, on a piano, the same string is used to play A-sharp and B-flat, but they are not really the same pitch.  Of course it would be entirely impractical to have a different key for all of the sharps and all of the flats... and even if you did, you would still have the same problem with double flats and double sharps.  So they tune the one string to somewhere between the two frequencies.  However, I did now know that they used the 12th root of 2 for calculating the interval between each note. This means that all the notes (except A) are slightly out of tune and not just the sharps and flats.

Tunings used to be based on perfect intervals. If you wanted to play in a different key, you'd have to retune the whole instrument. E.g. only the fifth between the first and fifth note in the scale would be perfect fifth, any other fifths would be slightly off and so on. The beauty of 12 tone equal temperament is that you can build a scale based on 7 notes starting from any note and be close enough to in tune that it's not unpleasant to the ear, and you don't have to retune the entire instrument every time you change key.

Another interesting aspect of the piano is the design of the white and black keys. All white keys gives you different kinds of 7-tone (heptatonic scales), e.g. C-major scale starting from C. All black keys gives you pentatonic scales. It's a kind of mnemonic device to remember where you are on the keyboard and it helps out beginners (you don't have to start with e.g. A# major, where you have to memorize which white and black keys belong to the scale; start with C-maj, it's just the white keys).

12-TET tuning won out in the end, but this was not a given. E.g. Huygens proposed 31-TET, the turks experimented with 53-TET and so on. The big advantage of 12-TET is that it's a lot easier to learn scales when there are only 12 keys in each octave, and it's close enough that going to 31-TET is not a huge advantage.

While he is explaining the tuning well, he isn't complete correct. Having one note in tune is not the same as having a chord (multiple notes played at the same time) in tune. For example. A Bb major triad is composed of a Bb, D, and F. And if you were to play each of these notes in tune, the chord wouldn't be in tune. depending on the Chord makes every note have a different tuning depending on it's location in the scale. So in the Bb scale the F is the fifth note in the scale and is raised 2 cents (distance from being "in tune") and the Third note of the chord (the D) is lowered 14 cents, while the Bb is perfectly in tune. Other notes also have a different place to be "in tune" So unless you only play one type of chord in the entire song, you can't have an "in tune" piano.

The video deals with the compromises caused by having just 12 notes in an octave, which are true also for all keyboard instruments and fretted strings, and not really anything specific to the piano. Pianos have their own larger issues. The upper partials are sharp, so a lower note is not normally tuned exactly an octave below the octave above. Rather, it's second "harmonic" is tuned with the upper octave. That makes the bass flatter and flatter, and the treble sharper. It's called a "stretched" tuning. It sounds better than if each note were tuned to the theoretical frequency. Also, it makes 12-note equal temperament sound pretty good, with the wildly out-of-tune major thirds adding some brilliance. In contrast, harpsichords sound much better in one of the historical meantone or "well" temperaments, unless they have to blend with other instruments tuned other ways.

Harmonicas (3 octave range for a diatonic) also have to pick a tuning scheme. Historically they were often used as chord instrument so they were tuned to a Just Temperament or a Compromise Temperament, but they can also be bought or retuned to ET.

Of course, diatonic harmonicas (also called blues harps or just harps) are both simpler and more complicated with their arrangement than a piano. Being diatonic instruments they are designed to play in just one key. (If you compared that to a piano in the key of C that would be just the white notes) but if you are a beginning diatonic harmonica player you have it a little bit easier than a piano player- while a piano player has to learn which black notes to hit for the other 11 major keys. A harp player will carry around a box of all 12 keys (or at least the more popular keys, which varies from genre to genre). Where the harp gets complicated compared to the piano is that instead of hitting the keys on the piano to make a note the harp player either blows or sucks (yes, there is a joke there- all harp players blow or suck) air through one or more different holes (a harp has 10 holes, a blow and draw reed in each hole). Because it's virtually impossible to play both a blow note and a draw note at the same time (it is possible with some weird tricks, but not very practical) and because the harmonica was designed to play chords they had to lay out the notes in a pattern that put the chords together as either blow or draw, at the expense of what would be a more straightforward progression of just having all the notes in order. This Richter tuning (in this case tuning is which notes are in which hole, not how many cents sharp or flat a specific note is from being dead on on a tuner) is used on most diatonic harmonicas, but people are always playing around with different tunings. Some harmonicas are laid out to make playing minor chords easier, some to play harmonic minor chords, some to play Irish music better, or others to be able to play more chromatically. On a regular Richter tuned harmonica only the middle of the three octaves has all the notes available without more advanced techniques-

But it gets even more complicated, because it turns out that you can use the resonance of the two reeds in the same hole to bend a note to a pitch that is not the natural sounding frequency of either reed, and that involves all sorts of crazy physics that isn't even that well figured out in the harmonica community. There are draw notes and blow bends, where the reeds sound a pitch in between the pitch of the two reeds and overblows where they sound higher. It involves all sorts of technique to get them to sound right. In general, and there is debate as to why this is, you can color the tone of draw notes better than blow notes, to the point that blues guys (as opposed to folk guys like Bob Dylan or Neil Young) don't usually play their harmonica in the key it was designed to play in. Instead, they play in a key a fifth off, so to play in G they would play on a C harmonica and bend some notes to make it fit.

All this, and unlike a lot of instruments, it's virtually impossible to see what you are doing. You have to feel around with your tongue and lips and figure out what hole you are on.

The harmonic, or just temperament, music system is why we have flats and sharps. In such a system E sharp is NOT F flat and there would be no enharmonic equivalents at all. The 12 tone equal temperament system allows all keys to overlap each other and 'nudges' the tones that would be close but not the same into equivalence. The result is that the semitone intervals from the next key either land on the same tone as the last key or exactly split the difference in the whole tone intervals and the player would simply skip those tones if not playing in that key.

An instrument like a violin can be played in either system (in theory) by a skilled enough player, however to play guitar in just temperament (the harmonic system) most frets would have to move sharp or flat, but only on some strings and you would have to move the frets (like on a sitar) or make a new instrument for each key you wanted to play in; something like the guitar shown here: http://www.billalves.com/porgitaro/porgitarotuning.html
with multiple fretboards, although I'm not sure if those pictured there are all for the different keys in a just temperament system or if he is branching out into even more diverse tuning and temperament systems

Musicians from the medieval times forward were tweaking the tuning systems until we stumbled on the 12 tone equal temperament system, so if you really dig there's all sorts of stuff out there, all just a bit different by not enough to really care about for most folks.

Just to be clear, all western fretted stringed instruments are tuned in equal temperament (including guitars), unless the fret spacing is specially designed for some other temperament. When a guitar is tuned using harmonics, you may have near perfectly tuned open strings, but the fretted notes will be slightly out of tune since the only perfect intervals in equal temperament are the unison and octave. The best tuning method other than a chromatic tuner is tuning by octaves from a common string.

This is a great video, but actually the harmonic tuning method is also fundamentally flawed. The harmonics on stringed instruments don't actually create perfect integers of the fundamental frequency. Due to the strings being physical things with tension, a phenomenon called inharmonicity occurs. This means that the harmonic frequencies actually slighty increase with each integer.
For example, if the fundamental frequency is 100 Hz, then the 1st harmonic may be 200.02 Hz and the 20th harmonic may be 2034 Hz. This means that when tuning a piano, using the equal temperament system, the higher keys will be sharp and the lower keys will be flat.
Interestingly, this is still how we tune pianos and when keyboards have been produced with "perfect" tuning, musicians and sound engineers have preferred the "imperfect" tuning. Perfectly tuned pianos sound wrong to us.

I think you glossed a bit over the fact that this isn't just a problem with pianos, but with all instruments that want to play in equal temperament.

For example: If you tune a guitar using harmonics, you end up with just fourths, but the frets are still spaced equally, so the fretted fourth will sound ~2 cents sharper.

Pretty much all non-classical music (and by today even most classical music, especially when including keyed or fretted instruments) uses equal temperament exclusively, so pure intervals (except for multiples of octaves) are pretty much not heard anymore. Most people's ears have gotten used to it and most musicians intone equal intervals because by now it is just what sounds right.

It's even worse than this. In a way, you can't even tune a piano well-tempered. When you tune a piano, you want the first higher harmonic of any note to be in tune with the fundamental mode of the tone one octave higher. The problem is that the amplitude of the oscillation is so large that the first harmonic is not exactly twice the frequency of the fundamental mode. As a result, a well-tuned piano diverges slightly from well-tempered towards the high and low ends. That also means that the harmony gets worse as the distance between tones increases. This effect is worse for shorter strings. That's the whole reason why concerts are given on grand pianos, not upright pianos.

There is also a different number of intervals in western and traditional middle eastern scales. Neither can achieve mathematical perfection by equal sub-divisions of an octave whether it's 16 intervals (western) or 24 intervals (traditional Arabian) AND achieve the kind of harmonics our ears enjoy. At the end of the day, it's best to tune 'by ear' because it's the results that matter even if it's mathematically arbitrary.

If that wasn't bad enough, a piano tuned to equal temperament sounds flat in the higher octaves. Piano tuners intentionally tune them sharp to sound good to the ear. By the way, string instruments are played in equal temperament too so you can't tune them with harmonics, just get close. An exception is the guitar, which has to be tuned harmonically in E or the chords beat. This is especially true when playing with a fuzz box. The distortion magnifies the beats. It's also why a distorted guitar only sounds good when playing certain chords (E and A in the open position).

It's this interplay between just and equal temperament that makes brass band playing, and barbershop singing, so difficult yet so pleasing. If you listen to a top bbshop quartet like Vocal Spectrum or Ringmasters you can audibly hear when they switch within a chord from equal to just tuning, it makes the chord really leap out and ring much more clearly, same with bands like Foden's. It's only possible to do this if you have access to a continuous spectrum of tuning, which is why (I think) it's much easier to get an orchestra, choir or band to sound 'perfect' and most pleasing than it is to acheive the same consonance with a piano, harpsichord, or organ. On the other hand, tuning a keyboard instrument justly then playing in a different key makes for really interesting sounds, a fact taken advantage of by Renaissance composers, for example if a harpsichord is tuned justly on C, then playing it in A minor results in a very 'cold' feeling, and G major feels quite uncomfortable and restless. I absolutely love exploring this kind of interplay between physics, music and psychology, I find it really satisfying
